abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Agricultural Sector
            Adjustment Loan for Pakistan was satisfactory. The project
            has partially achieved its objectives, the strengthening of
            institutions is progressing, sustainability is likely, and
            the performance of both the Bank and Borrower was
            satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, action was more timely in the areas of
            federal government responsibilities than those of the
            provincial governments. Second, there is a need for critical
            appraisal of implementing agencies, especially those dealing
            with programs that require difficult decisions on economic
            reforms with wide political implications. Third, staff
            requirements for program loans should not be underestimated.
            Fourth, the ASAL focused on a few important issues rather
            than attempting to deal with a broader range. Fifth, it is
            important to combine reform programs with concurrent efforts
            in the same area. Finally, it may be useful to adjust
            procurement procedures in program loans, depending on
            whether the importers are in the public or private sector.
